question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
For some value of $x,$ $0 < x < 180,$
\[\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ \tan x^\circ = \tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ + \tan x^\circ.\]Find $x.$
inference:
We can write
\begin{align*}
\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ \tan x^\circ &= \tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ + \tan x^\circ \\
&= \frac{\sin 53^\circ}{\cos 53^\circ} + \frac{\sin 81^\circ}{\cos 81^\circ} + \frac{\sin x^\circ}{\cos x^\circ} \\
&= \frac{\sin 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \cos x^\circ + \cos 53^\circ \sin 81^\circ \cos x^\circ + \cos 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \sin x^\circ}{\cos 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \cos x^\circ}.
\end{align*}Then
\[\sin 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \cos x^\circ + \cos 53^\circ \sin 81^\circ \cos x^\circ + \cos 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \sin x^\circ = \sin 53^\circ \sin 81^\circ \sin x^\circ.\]By the angle addition formula,
\[\sin (53^\circ + 81^\circ) \cos x^\circ + \cos 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \sin x^\circ = \sin 53^\circ \sin 81^\circ \sin x^\circ.\]Then
\[\sin 134^\circ \cos x^\circ + \cos 53^\circ \cos 81^\circ \sin x^\circ = \sin 53^\circ \sin 81^\circ \sin x^\circ.\]By the angle subtraction formula,
\[\sin (134^\circ - x^\circ) = \sin 53^\circ \sin 81^\circ \sin x^\circ.\]Since $0 < x < 180,$ $0 < 134 - x < 134,$ so
\[\sin (134 - x)^\circ = \sin x^\circ.\]Thus, $134 - x = x,$ so $x = \boxed{67}.$
Final Answer: $\boxed{67}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Isolating $\tan x^\circ,$ we find
\begin{align*}
\tan x &= \frac{\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ}{\tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ - 1} \\
&= -\frac{\tan 53^\circ + \tan 81^\circ}{1 - \tan 53^\circ \tan 81^\circ}.
\end{align*}From the angle addition formula, this is equal to
\[-\tan (53^\circ + 81^\circ) = -\tan 134^\circ = \tan 46^\circ.\]Therefore, $x = \boxed{46}.$
